questions.text: Pencil is fine for Section B if your writing is neat.
questions.explanation: Use ink pen for Section B. Papers are scanned, and pencil often comes out too faint for assessors to read reliably.
questions.studyTip: Bring a reliable pen. Pencil is only for diagrams and graphs.

questions.text: Assessors mark scanned images, so ink pen is essential for Section B.
questions.explanation: Papers are scanned, not marked directly. Ink shows up clearly; pencil can be unreadable.
questions.studyTip: Dark blue or black ink works best for scanning.

questions.text: For multi-mark questions, showing working is optional if your final answer is correct.
questions.explanation: Working is mandatory for questions worth more than 1 mark. Marks reward demonstrated understanding, not just correct answers.
questions.studyTip: No working = no marks, even if the answer is right.

questions.text: Marks are given for each step in your working, not just the final answer.
questions.explanation: Each step shows understanding. Partial credit comes from correct method even if arithmetic slips.
questions.studyTip: Write the formula, substitution, then answer — every time.

questions.text: Writing just the option letter is enough when asked to 'explain your answer'.
questions.explanation: You must justify your choice. A letter alone with no reasoning is treated as a guess and scores zero.
questions.studyTip: See 'explain' or 'justify'? Write WHY, not just WHAT.

questions.text: Questions asking you to justify your answer require reasoning, not just a selection.
questions.explanation: Even with only two options, you must show you understand why one is correct.
questions.studyTip: Explain the physics principle that supports your choice.

questions.text: If your working doesn't give the expected answer, adjust the numbers to match.
questions.explanation: Never fudge answers. Assessors spot inconsistent working immediately. Find and fix the actual error.
questions.studyTip: If it doesn't add up, redo it — don't fake it.

questions.text: Your calculation steps must logically lead to your stated final answer.
questions.explanation: Assessors check that working matches the answer. Mismatched values suggest copying or guessing.
questions.studyTip: Double-check: does my arithmetic actually give this number?

questions.text: Diagrams are only allowed when the question specifically asks for one.
questions.explanation: You can always add diagrams to clarify your thinking. They're especially helpful for forces, projectiles, and circuits.
questions.studyTip: When in doubt, draw it out.

questions.text: Drawing a force diagram can help communicate your understanding even when not required.
questions.explanation: Clear diagrams show systematic thinking and can earn marks by making your reasoning visible.
questions.studyTip: Label all forces with symbols and directions.

questions.text: For long questions, start calculating immediately to save time.
questions.explanation: Rushing in causes disorganised, incomplete work. Take a moment to plan your approach first.
questions.studyTip: 30 seconds planning saves 3 minutes fixing mistakes.

questions.text: Planning your strategy before starting helps produce organised, complete solutions.
questions.explanation: Know what you need to find, what to calculate first, and what to compare. Then execute systematically.
questions.studyTip: Ask: What am I finding? What do I need? What's my method?

questions.text: To convert milliseconds to seconds, multiply by 1000.
questions.explanation: Divide by 1000. Example: 240 ms = 0.240 s. Milli means thousandth.
questions.studyTip: ms → s: divide by 1000. km → m: multiply by 1000.

questions.text: Common errors include forgetting to convert km to m or GV to V.
questions.explanation: Always check units before substituting. km → m: ×1000. GV → V: ×10⁹.
questions.studyTip: Write unit conversions as a separate line in your working.

questions.text: If the answer box shows 'kW', you can answer in any power unit if you label it.
questions.explanation: When a unit is specified, you must use that exact unit. Answering in W when kW is required loses marks.
questions.studyTip: Check the answer box unit BEFORE you write anything.

questions.text: The unit in the answer box tells you exactly which unit your answer must use.
questions.explanation: This is a direct instruction. Convert your calculated value to match the required unit.
questions.studyTip: Box says kW? Answer in kW. No exceptions.

questions.text: Give as many decimal places as your calculator shows to demonstrate accuracy.
questions.explanation: Use 2–3 significant figures unless told otherwise. Excessive precision suggests you don't understand measurement uncertainty.
questions.studyTip: Calculator says 9.81234567? Write 9.81.

questions.text: Final answers should typically have 2–3 significant figures.
questions.explanation: This matches the precision of given data and shows appropriate understanding of experimental uncertainty.
questions.studyTip: Match your answer's precision to the question's data.

questions.text: When finding a gradient, use data points from the original table.
questions.explanation: Use points ON YOUR DRAWN LINE, not table values. The gradient represents your fitted trend, not raw data.
questions.studyTip: Pick two points clearly on your line, far apart.

questions.text: Gradient calculations must use points from your line of best fit, showing (y₂−y₁)/(x₂−x₁).
questions.explanation: Points far apart reduce error. Show the formula and substitution clearly.
questions.studyTip: Mark your chosen points on the graph with small crosses.

questions.text: For graph analysis, getting the right number matters more than showing how you found it.
questions.explanation: These questions test whether you understand what the gradient represents physically. Show the full process.
questions.studyTip: State: gradient = [formula] = [physical constant].

questions.text: Questions about finding constants from graphs test your understanding of what the gradient represents.
questions.explanation: You must connect the mathematical gradient to its physical meaning (e.g., gradient = h in photoelectric effect).
questions.studyTip: Always write: 'Therefore, [constant] = gradient × [other terms]'.

questions.text: In projectile motion, g should be positive since gravity causes the motion.
questions.explanation: If up is positive, g = −9.8 m s⁻². Gravity acts downward. Stay consistent throughout the problem.
questions.studyTip: Define your positive direction first. Stick to it.

questions.text: Consistent sign conventions prevent errors in vector calculations.
questions.explanation: Define positive direction at the start. Apply it to all quantities: displacement, velocity, acceleration, force.
questions.studyTip: Write 'Taking up as positive' before you start.

questions.text: Change in momentum is just the difference between final and initial speeds.
questions.explanation: Momentum is a vector: Δp = p_final − p_initial. Direction matters. A ball bouncing back changes momentum by more than 2mv.
questions.studyTip: Draw before and after arrows. Subtract vectors, not just numbers.

questions.text: The sign of Δp tells you the direction of the momentum change.
questions.explanation: Positive Δp means change in your defined positive direction. This connects to the direction of the net impulse.
questions.studyTip: Δp positive → net impulse was in positive direction.

questions.text: For vector quantities, stating the number is enough without mentioning direction.
questions.explanation: Vectors require both magnitude and direction. '14 kg m s⁻¹' is incomplete. '14 kg m s⁻¹ upward' is correct.
questions.studyTip: Force, velocity, momentum, acceleration — always give direction.

questions.text: Complete vector answers include both magnitude and direction.
questions.explanation: Omitting direction loses marks. Use words (up, left, north) or angles (37° above horizontal).
questions.studyTip: Check: Is this a vector? Did I state direction?

questions.text: Impulse can only be calculated using I = FΔt with average force.
questions.explanation: Impulse equals the area under a force-time graph. For triangles: ½ × base × height. You can also count grid squares.
questions.studyTip: Variable force? Find the area, not F × t.

questions.text: The area under a force-time graph gives impulse, calculated geometrically.
questions.explanation: Split complex shapes into triangles and rectangles. Add the areas. This gives total impulse.
questions.studyTip: Triangle: ½bh. Rectangle: bh. Add them up.

questions.text: If you know the formula, you don't need to check whether it applies to the situation.
questions.explanation: Many students use wrong formulas (range equation when heights differ, sin instead of cos). Verify the formula fits.
questions.studyTip: Ask: What assumptions does this formula make? Do they hold here?

questions.text: Common errors include using formulas that don't apply to the given situation.
questions.explanation: Range formulas assume equal launch and landing heights. Memorised formulas need careful application.
questions.studyTip: Derive from basics if unsure. It's safer than wrong formula.

questions.text: In force problems, only include forces that cause motion.
questions.explanation: Include ALL forces: friction, air resistance, normal force, weight — even if some cancel out.
questions.studyTip: Draw a free body diagram. Label every force.

questions.text: Common errors include forgetting friction or using wrong mass in ΣF = ma.
questions.explanation: Systematic force analysis prevents omissions. List forces before calculating.
questions.studyTip: Checklist: Weight? Normal? Friction? Tension? Applied? Air resistance?

concepts.title: Lines of best fit use ALL points

questions.text: A line of best fit should connect the first and last data points.
questions.explanation: This is wrong. The line must consider ALL points, with roughly equal numbers above and below it.
questions.studyTip: If all middle points are on one side, your line is wrong.

questions.text: A good line of best fit has roughly equal points above and below it.
questions.explanation: The line represents the overall trend, minimising total distance to all points.
questions.studyTip: Use a transparent ruler. Adjust until points balance.

questions.text: Calculate gradient using the original data points from the table.
questions.explanation: Use points ON YOUR LINE, not raw data. The gradient represents your fitted trend.
questions.studyTip: Data points might not be on your line. Line points must be.

questions.text: Select two points on your line of best fit, spaced far apart, for gradient calculation.
questions.explanation: Greater separation reduces percentage error. Both points must lie on your drawn line.
questions.studyTip: Use points near the edges of your line for best accuracy.

questions.text: If your gradient gives an unexpected value, adjust your points to get closer to the theoretical value.
questions.explanation: Never manipulate data. Calculate honestly. Real experiments have uncertainty.
questions.studyTip: Your job is to measure accurately, not match textbook values.

questions.text: Calculated values from experiments may differ slightly from theoretical values due to uncertainty.
questions.explanation: Discuss sources of error if asked. Don't pretend your results are perfect.
questions.studyTip: Small discrepancies are normal. Large ones need explanation.

questions.text: When finding constants from graphs, just state the value you calculated.
questions.explanation: Show HOW the gradient relates to the constant. Write: gradient = k/2mg, therefore k = gradient × 2mg.
questions.studyTip: Equation → gradient meaning → substitute → constant value.

questions.text: You must show the relationship between gradient and the physical constant you're finding.
questions.explanation: The study design requires understanding 'the physical significance of the gradient of linearised data'.
questions.studyTip: Compare y = mx + c with your physics equation. What does m represent?

questions.text: Plotting raw data is always better than linearising because it shows actual measurements.
questions.explanation: Linearising (e.g., plotting x² vs h instead of x vs h) creates straight lines, making gradient analysis easier and more accurate.
questions.studyTip: Curved graph? Transform variables to get a straight line.

questions.text: Plotting y vs x² transforms y = kx² into a straight line with gradient k.
questions.explanation: Straight lines are easier to analyse. The gradient directly gives the constant you need.
questions.studyTip: Know common linearisations: T² vs l, v² vs 1/r, ln(A) vs t.

questions.text: In projectile motion without air resistance, both horizontal and vertical velocities change.
questions.explanation: Horizontal velocity stays constant (no horizontal force). Only vertical velocity changes due to gravity.
questions.studyTip: Horizontal: constant v. Vertical: constant a = g.

questions.text: Horizontal velocity in projectile motion remains constant when air resistance is negligible.
questions.explanation: No horizontal force means no horizontal acceleration. vₓ = constant throughout flight.
questions.studyTip: Treat x and y motion separately. They're independent.

questions.text: Air resistance only reduces horizontal distance, not maximum height.
questions.explanation: Air resistance reduces BOTH maximum height and range. It removes kinetic energy throughout the flight.
questions.studyTip: Air resistance opposes motion in all directions.

questions.text: Air resistance reduces both maximum height and horizontal range of a projectile.
questions.explanation: Energy is lost to air resistance continuously. Less energy means lower peak and shorter range.
questions.studyTip: With air resistance: lower, shorter, asymmetric path.

questions.text: The range equation works whenever you know initial velocity and launch angle.
questions.explanation: Range equations assume launch and landing heights are equal. Different heights require full kinematic analysis.
questions.studyTip: Cliff edge launch? Can't use range formula. Use kinematics.

questions.text: Standard range formulas only work when launch and landing heights are the same.
questions.explanation: For different heights: find time from vertical motion first, then calculate horizontal distance.
questions.studyTip: Check: Same height at start and end? If not, use suvat.

questions.text: A ball on a string in circular motion has three forces: weight, tension, and centripetal force.
questions.explanation: Only TWO forces: weight (down) and tension (along string). Centripetal force isn't a separate force — it's the net horizontal component.
questions.studyTip: Centripetal force = result of real forces, not an extra force.

questions.text: The horizontal component of tension provides the centripetal force for a conical pendulum.
questions.explanation: Tension has vertical component (balances weight) and horizontal component (provides centripetal acceleration).
questions.studyTip: Draw force diagram. Resolve tension into components.

questions.text: On a banked curve, the normal force points directly toward the centre of the turn.
questions.explanation: Normal force is perpendicular to the surface, pointing at an angle above the centre. Its horizontal component provides centripetal force.
questions.studyTip: Normal = perpendicular to surface. Always.

questions.text: On a banked curve, the normal force is perpendicular to the track, not pointing at the centre.
questions.explanation: The horizontal component of normal force provides centripetal acceleration. The vertical component balances weight.
questions.studyTip: Resolve N into Ncosθ (vertical) and Nsinθ (horizontal).

questions.text: Kinetic energy has direction because it depends on velocity, which is a vector.
questions.explanation: KE = ½mv². It depends on speed (v²), not velocity. KE is a scalar — magnitude only, no direction.
questions.studyTip: KE cares how fast, not which way.

questions.text: A projectile at constant speed has constant KE even though velocity direction changes.
questions.explanation: KE depends only on speed. Changing direction at constant speed doesn't change KE.
questions.studyTip: Scalar = no direction. KE, mass, energy, time are scalars.

questions.text: An object moving at constant speed in a circle has constant momentum.
questions.explanation: Momentum p = mv is a vector. Constant speed but changing direction means changing momentum. That's why circular motion needs a net force.
questions.studyTip: Constant speed ≠ constant momentum if direction changes.

questions.text: Momentum changes when direction changes, even if speed stays constant.
questions.explanation: Momentum has magnitude AND direction. New direction = new momentum = Δp ≠ 0.
questions.studyTip: Vector changes if magnitude OR direction changes.

questions.text: A collision is inelastic if momentum is not conserved.
questions.explanation: Momentum is ALWAYS conserved in collisions (isolated system). Inelastic means kinetic energy is not conserved.
questions.studyTip: Inelastic: momentum conserved, KE not conserved.

questions.text: In an inelastic collision, final KE is less than initial KE.
questions.explanation: Some KE converts to heat, sound, deformation. Total energy conserved, but KE specifically decreases.
questions.studyTip: KE 'lost' → other forms (heat, sound, deformation).

questions.text: Saying 'energy is not conserved' is enough when explaining inelastic collisions.
questions.explanation: Total energy is ALWAYS conserved. You must say KINETIC energy is not conserved. Precision matters.
questions.studyTip: Write 'kinetic energy' not just 'energy'.

questions.text: You must distinguish between total energy (always conserved) and kinetic energy (may not be conserved).
questions.explanation: Total energy includes heat, sound, potential energy. KE is just the ½mv² part.
questions.studyTip: Inelastic: KE decreases, but total energy stays same.

questions.text: g = 9.8 N kg⁻¹ can be used at any altitude above Earth's surface.
questions.explanation: g = GM/r². As altitude increases, r increases, so g decreases. At satellite altitudes, g is much less than 9.8.
questions.studyTip: g at 400 km altitude ≈ 8.7 N kg⁻¹. Significant difference.

questions.text: Gravitational field strength decreases with altitude following an inverse square law.
questions.explanation: g ∝ 1/r². Double the distance from Earth's centre, g drops to ¼.
questions.studyTip: Use g = GM/r² for any altitude. Don't assume 9.8.

questions.text: If orbital velocity changes, orbital radius can stay the same.
questions.explanation: v = √(GM/r). Each radius has exactly one stable orbital velocity. Change v, must change r.
questions.studyTip: Want to go faster? Move to lower orbit. v and r are linked.

questions.text: Orbital velocity depends on orbital radius: v = √(GM/r).
questions.explanation: Closer orbits are faster. The ISS at 400 km does 7.7 km s⁻¹. Geostationary at 36,000 km does 3.1 km s⁻¹.
questions.studyTip: Lower orbit = higher speed. Higher orbit = lower speed.

questions.text: To check if an orbit works, calculating either the required force or available force is enough.
questions.explanation: Calculate BOTH, then compare. Available gravity vs required centripetal. Do they match?
questions.studyTip: Strategy: Find F_gravity. Find F_centripetal needed. Compare.

questions.text: Orbit problems need comparison: available force vs required force, or calculated v vs given v.
questions.explanation: The comparison IS the answer. Without it, you've just done calculations with no conclusion.
questions.studyTip: Always end with: 'Since X > Y, the orbit is/isn't possible.'

questions.text: Magnetic force on a current-carrying wire is maximum when wire is parallel to field.
questions.explanation: F = BIL sin θ. When parallel (θ = 0°), sin 0 = 0, so F = 0. Maximum force when perpendicular.
questions.studyTip: Parallel to field = no force. Perpendicular = max force.

questions.text: When current is parallel to the magnetic field, the force on the wire is zero.
questions.explanation: F = BIL sin θ. At θ = 0°, force is zero. This explains why some coil orientations produce no torque.
questions.studyTip: Use right-hand slap rule to find force direction.

questions.text: Slip rings and split ring commutators do the same thing in motors and generators.
questions.explanation: Slip rings: continuous contact, AC output (generators). Split ring commutators: reverse connections, DC output (motors).
questions.studyTip: Slip rings → AC. Split ring → DC. Different jobs.

questions.text: Slip rings maintain continuous contact to transfer AC from a spinning coil.
questions.explanation: Slip rings allow current to flow continuously without reversing polarity. Essential for AC generators.
questions.studyTip: Generator → slip rings → AC. Motor → commutator → DC.

questions.text: A constant magnetic field through a coil produces a constant induced current.
questions.explanation: Constant flux = zero induced EMF. Only CHANGING flux induces current (Faraday's law).
questions.studyTip: No change = no induction. Δ is essential.

questions.text: By Faraday's law, only changing magnetic flux induces an EMF.
questions.explanation: ε = −ΔΦ/Δt. If Φ is constant, ΔΦ = 0, so ε = 0. Change is everything.
questions.studyTip: Moving magnet = changing flux = EMF. Stationary = nothing.

questions.text: Transformers work with DC because they transfer energy through magnetic fields.
questions.explanation: DC creates constant flux → no induction in secondary. Transformers REQUIRE AC for the changing flux.
questions.studyTip: DC into transformer = nothing out. Must be AC.

questions.text: Transformers require AC to create the changing flux needed for induction in the secondary.
questions.explanation: AC oscillates → flux oscillates → EMF induced in secondary. That's how energy transfers.
questions.studyTip: AC frequency in = AC frequency out. Voltage ratio depends on turns ratio.

questions.text: In a series circuit, current varies through different components based on their resistance.
questions.explanation: Current is identical through all components in series. There's only one path, so charge flows at the same rate everywhere.
questions.studyTip: Series = same current. Think of water in a single pipe.

questions.text: Current through every component in a series circuit is the same.
questions.explanation: One path = one current. What goes in must come out. Resistance affects voltage drop, not current.
questions.studyTip: Measure current anywhere in series — same reading.

questions.text: In parallel circuits, voltage across each branch depends on that branch's resistance.
questions.explanation: Voltage is identical across all parallel branches. Current varies with resistance (I = V/R), not voltage.
questions.studyTip: Parallel = same voltage across each branch.

questions.text: All branches in a parallel circuit have the same voltage across them.
questions.explanation: Parallel branches connect to the same two points. Same start and end = same potential difference.
questions.studyTip: Higher resistance branch → less current, same voltage.

questions.text: Electric field lines point toward positive charges and away from negative charges.
questions.explanation: Opposite: field lines point AWAY from positive, TOWARD negative. They show force direction on a positive test charge.
questions.studyTip: Field lines start at + and end at −. Always.

questions.text: Electric field lines show the direction a positive test charge would be pushed.
questions.explanation: By definition, E field points in the direction of force on a positive charge. Away from +, toward −.
questions.studyTip: Positive test charge follows field lines. Negative goes opposite.

questions.text: Between two like charges, the electric field is very strong because fields add together.
questions.explanation: Between like charges, fields point opposite directions and partially cancel. Net field approaches zero at the midpoint.
questions.studyTip: Like charges: fields oppose between them. Unlike: fields add.

questions.text: Gravitational forces always attract; electric forces can attract or repel.
questions.explanation: Gravity has only one 'sign' of mass. Electric charge comes in + and −, allowing both attraction and repulsion.
questions.studyTip: Gravity: always attractive. Electric: depends on charge signs.

questions.text: The speed of light is constant in all transparent media including glass and water.
questions.explanation: Light speed is only constant in vacuum (c). In media, v = c/n where n > 1, so light slows down.
questions.studyTip: Glass n ≈ 1.5 means light travels at ⅔ of c in glass.

questions.text: Light travels slower in glass than vacuum because the refractive index exceeds 1.
questions.explanation: n = c/v_medium. Since n > 1, v_medium < c. Higher n means slower light.
questions.studyTip: Diamond n = 2.4 → light at less than half its vacuum speed.

questions.text: Total internal reflection can happen when light goes from air into glass.
questions.explanation: TIR only occurs going from higher n to lower n (e.g., glass → air) AND exceeding the critical angle.
questions.studyTip: TIR: must be in denser medium, heading to less dense.

questions.text: TIR requires light travelling from higher to lower refractive index, beyond the critical angle.
questions.explanation: Critical angle: sin θc = n₂/n₁ where n₁ > n₂. Below critical angle: refraction. Above: total reflection.
questions.studyTip: Fibre optics trap light using TIR at glass-air boundary.

questions.text: Diffraction only occurs when wavelength is smaller than the gap width.
questions.explanation: Diffraction occurs at any wavelength/gap ratio. The EXTENT of spreading depends on λ/d, not whether it happens.
questions.studyTip: Diffraction always happens. How much depends on λ/d.

questions.text: The amount of diffraction depends on the ratio of wavelength to gap width.
questions.explanation: λ/d ≈ 1 gives most noticeable diffraction. Larger λ or smaller d means more spreading.
questions.studyTip: Sound diffracts around corners easily (long λ). Light doesn't (short λ).

questions.text: Different diffraction pattern spacings always mean different gap widths were used.
questions.explanation: Spacing Δx = λL/d. Different spacing can mean different wavelength, not just different gap.
questions.studyTip: Same apparatus, different spacing → different wavelength.

questions.text: Identical diffraction pattern spacing means identical wavelengths, regardless of source type.
questions.explanation: Electron and photon with same pattern spacing have same wavelength — despite being different particles.
questions.studyTip: Wavelength determines pattern. Particle type doesn't matter.

concepts.title: Time dilation is observed, not experienced

questions.text: A moving object experiences time dilation and ages more slowly.
questions.explanation: Moving objects don't 'experience' dilation. Time passes normally for them. OTHER observers see their time as dilated.
questions.studyTip: You never feel your own time slow down. Others measure it.

questions.text: Time dilation describes what a stationary observer measures for a moving clock, not what the moving clock experiences.
questions.explanation: The muon doesn't feel time slow down. Earth observers measure its lifetime as extended: t = γt₀.
questions.studyTip: In YOUR frame, your clock always ticks normally.

questions.text: Length contraction affects all dimensions of a moving object equally.
questions.explanation: Contraction only occurs parallel to motion. Perpendicular dimensions are unchanged.
questions.studyTip: Train moving horizontally: shorter horizontally, same height.

questions.text: Only measurements parallel to the direction of motion are contracted.
questions.explanation: L = L₀/γ applies only to the direction of relative motion. A sphere becomes an ellipsoid.
questions.studyTip: Moving toward you? Shortened in that direction only.

questions.text: The best relativity explanations combine both time dilation and length contraction.
questions.explanation: Pick ONE approach and stick to it. Mixing them often creates contradictions and confusion.
questions.studyTip: Earth frame → time dilation. Particle frame → length contraction. Not both.

questions.text: Solve relativity problems using either time dilation OR length contraction, not both together.
questions.explanation: Choose a frame, apply one phenomenon consistently. Both give the same final answer if done correctly.
questions.studyTip: Commit to one explanation. See it through.

questions.text: Intense light below threshold frequency will eventually emit photoelectrons if you wait long enough.
questions.explanation: Below threshold, no emission occurs regardless of intensity or time. Each photon must have hf ≥ W. More weak photons doesn't help.
questions.studyTip: Dim UV → electrons. Bright red → nothing. Frequency matters, intensity doesn't.

questions.text: The existence of a threshold frequency supports the particle model of light.
questions.explanation: Wave model predicted any frequency works with enough intensity. Particle model correctly requires individual photon energy hf ≥ W.
questions.studyTip: Threshold frequency was key evidence against wave model.

questions.text: Stopping voltage measures the maximum kinetic energy of photons.
questions.explanation: Photons come IN. PhotoELECTRONS come OUT. Stopping voltage measures electron KE, not photon energy.
questions.studyTip: Photon = light particle. Photoelectron = ejected electron.

questions.text: In photoelectric effect, photoelectrons are the particles ejected; photons are the incident light.
questions.explanation: Photon energy → electron kinetic energy (minus work function). Keep the terms straight.
questions.studyTip: hf = W + KE_max. Photon energy becomes electron KE.

questions.text: Increasing light intensity increases the maximum KE of individual photoelectrons.
questions.explanation: Intensity affects NUMBER of electrons (photocurrent), not individual energy. KE_max = hf − W depends on frequency only.
questions.studyTip: Brighter = more electrons. Higher frequency = faster electrons.

questions.text: Maximum photoelectron kinetic energy increases with frequency, not intensity.
questions.explanation: Each photon gives one electron energy hf. Higher f means more energy per photon, more KE after overcoming W.
questions.studyTip: To get faster electrons, increase frequency. Intensity won't help.

questions.text: Photocurrent stays constant regardless of intensity if frequency exceeds threshold.
questions.explanation: Higher intensity = more photons/second = more electrons/second = higher photocurrent.
questions.studyTip: Photocurrent ∝ intensity (above threshold).

questions.text: At constant frequency above threshold, photocurrent is proportional to light intensity.
questions.explanation: More photons → more photoelectrons → higher current. Linear relationship.
questions.studyTip: Double the intensity, double the photocurrent (same frequency).

questions.text: Using a different metal changes the gradient of the V_stop vs frequency graph.
questions.explanation: Gradient = h/e (Planck's constant / electron charge). Universal, same for all metals. Only the intercept changes.
questions.studyTip: Different metal → different intercept (work function). Same gradient.

questions.text: Planck's constant can be found from the gradient of any metal's V_stop vs f graph.
questions.explanation: V_s = (h/e)f − W/e. Gradient = h/e regardless of metal. Intercept = −W/e varies with metal.
questions.studyTip: Gradient gives h. Intercepts give different work functions.

questions.text: An electron and photon with the same energy produce identical diffraction patterns.
questions.explanation: Pattern spacing depends on wavelength. λ = h/p depends on momentum, not energy. Same energy ≠ same momentum for different particles.
questions.studyTip: Same energy, different mass → different momentum → different λ.

questions.text: de Broglie wavelength depends on momentum, so equal-energy particles can have different wavelengths.
questions.explanation: λ = h/p. For photons: p = E/c. For particles: p = √(2mE). Different masses give different p at same E.
questions.studyTip: Heavier particle at same energy → more momentum → shorter λ.

questions.text: In electron-positron annihilation, gamma rays can travel in any direction if total energy is conserved.
questions.explanation: Must conserve momentum too. Initial momentum ≈ 0, so the two photons must have equal and opposite momenta → opposite directions.
questions.studyTip: Two photons, opposite directions, equal energy. Momentum: zero before = zero after.

questions.text: Gamma rays from pair annihilation travel in opposite directions to conserve momentum.
questions.explanation: If e⁻ and e⁺ are nearly stationary, total momentum ≈ 0. Two photons with opposite momenta: p₁ + p₂ = 0.
questions.studyTip: 180° apart. Each photon carries 0.511 MeV.

questions.text: For e⁻e⁺ annihilation energy, use one electron mass since they cancel out.
questions.explanation: Both particles convert to energy. E = 2m_e c². Two particles = twice the mass-energy.
questions.studyTip: Electron + positron = 2 × 0.511 MeV = 1.022 MeV total.

questions.text: Annihilation energy equals the combined mass of both particles times c².
questions.explanation: E = mc² where m is total mass converted. Both e⁻ and e⁺ disappear, both contribute energy.
questions.studyTip: Each photon gets half: 0.511 MeV each.

questions.text: Restating the question in your answer shows you understand what was asked.
questions.explanation: 'When horizontal because it is horizontal' is circular reasoning. You must explain WHY — the physics mechanism.
questions.studyTip: If your 'because' just repeats the question, it's not an explanation.

questions.text: Explanations must provide reasoning beyond restating what the question already said.
questions.explanation: Good: 'When horizontal, current is parallel to field, so F = BIL sin 0° = 0.' That explains the mechanism.
questions.studyTip: Ask yourself: Have I explained HOW or WHY?

questions.text: Free body diagrams waste time if you can visualise the forces mentally.
questions.explanation: Diagrams prevent errors and show assessors your reasoning. They help you systematically identify all forces.
questions.studyTip: 2 minutes drawing saves 5 minutes finding mistakes.

questions.text: Free body diagrams communicate your understanding and prevent missed forces.
questions.explanation: Assessors value clear diagrams. They prove you've considered all forces systematically.
questions.studyTip: Label every arrow: type of force, magnitude if known, direction.

questions.text: Having formulas on your reference sheet means you can copy them into any relevant question.
questions.explanation: Copying without adapting to the specific question scores zero. Apply formulas appropriately to each situation.
questions.studyTip: Reference sheet = tools. You still need to use them correctly.

questions.text: Assessors recognise disjointed facts copied from notes versus considered responses.
questions.explanation: Random formula dumps that don't address the question demonstrate lack of understanding.
questions.studyTip: Read the question. Think. Then use relevant parts of your notes.

questions.text: Mentioning assumptions suggests your answer might be wrong, so avoid them.
questions.explanation: Stating assumptions shows sophisticated understanding. 'Assuming negligible air resistance...' demonstrates awareness of model limitations.
questions.studyTip: Good physics acknowledges what's being simplified.

questions.text: Explicitly stating assumptions demonstrates understanding of model limitations.
questions.explanation: Recognising what you've assumed (friction = 0, point mass, uniform field) shows depth beyond plugging numbers.
questions.studyTip: Common assumptions: no air resistance, g constant, ideal springs.

questions.text: Correct calculations are enough even without explicitly answering what was asked.
questions.explanation: If asked 'will this work?', you must say yes or no with justification. Calculations alone don't answer the question.
questions.studyTip: Read the question again after calculating. Did you actually answer it?

questions.text: When asked to determine if something works, state your conclusion explicitly after calculating.
questions.explanation: 'Since F_gravity < F_required, the orbit is not possible.' The comparison and conclusion are the answer.
questions.studyTip: Finish with a clear statement that directly answers the question.

questions.text: Analyse the entire projectile path in one calculation to avoid errors.
questions.explanation: Separate horizontal and vertical motion. Horizontal: constant velocity. Vertical: constant acceleration. Then combine.
questions.studyTip: x and y are independent. Solve separately, link through time.

questions.text: Analysing horizontal and vertical components separately simplifies projectile problems.
questions.explanation: Horizontal: vₓ = constant. Vertical: use suvat with a = −g. Find time from one, use in other.
questions.studyTip: Time is what connects the two components.

questions.text: Once calculated, move on immediately to save time for other questions.
questions.explanation: Quick sense-check: Is this reasonable? A person weighing 7000 N or v > c signals an error.
questions.studyTip: 10 seconds checking beats 5 minutes on a wrong answer.

questions.text: Checking if your answer is physically reasonable helps catch errors.
questions.explanation: Ask: Right magnitude? Right units? Right sign? Does this make physical sense?
questions.studyTip: Car at 500 m s⁻¹? Probably wrong. Double-check.

questions.text: Using the same phrases repeatedly shows consistency and clarity.
questions.explanation: Repetitive phrasing suggests copying without thinking. Vary your explanations naturally.
questions.studyTip: If you understand it, you can say it different ways.

questions.text: Expressing concepts in your own words shows genuine understanding.
questions.explanation: Exact repetition of textbook phrases suggests memorisation without comprehension.
questions.studyTip: Explain it like you're teaching a friend. Natural language is fine.

questions.text: Motors and generators both use coils in fields, so the same explanation works for both.
questions.explanation: Motors: electrical → kinetic. Generators: kinetic → electrical. Opposite energy conversions. Don't confuse them.
questions.studyTip: Motor uses current. Generator produces current. Know which is which.

questions.text: Confusing motors with generators, or slip rings with commutators, loses marks.
questions.explanation: These distinctions appear every exam. Know the specific function of each device.
questions.studyTip: Make a comparison table: motor vs generator, slip ring vs commutator.

questions.text: Past examiner reports just show answers and aren't useful for improving.
questions.explanation: Reports reveal common errors, model answers, and what assessors want. Invaluable for avoiding predictable mistakes.
questions.studyTip: Reports tell you exactly how students lose marks. Learn from them.

questions.text: Examiner reports show common errors and what assessors expect in complete answers.
questions.explanation: They explicitly state minimum required working and frequent mistakes. Use them.
questions.studyTip: Read reports for the last 3 years. Patterns emerge.

questions.text: Units 3 & 4 Physics is independent of Units 1 & 2, so earlier material doesn't matter.
questions.explanation: Units 3 & 4 build on earlier concepts. Weak foundations in circuits, forces, or energy cause ongoing problems.
questions.studyTip: Struggling? Review Unit 1 & 2 fundamentals.

questions.text: Mastering Units 1 & 2 concepts is essential for success in Units 3 & 4.
questions.explanation: Series/parallel circuits, vector addition, energy conservation — all carry forward. Gaps compound.
questions.studyTip: Units 3 & 4 assume you already know basic circuits, forces, energy.

questions.text: Writing everything you know about a topic ensures you get full marks.
questions.explanation: Answer what's asked, nothing more. Irrelevant information wastes time and suggests you don't understand the question.
questions.studyTip: 2-mark question ≠ essay. Be concise and targeted.

questions.text: Match the detail in your answer to the marks available.
questions.explanation: 1 mark: brief answer. 3 marks: calculation + comparison + conclusion. Scale your response.
questions.studyTip: Marks = roughly how many distinct things to include.

questions.text: General terms like 'energy' instead of 'kinetic energy' are fine since context makes it clear.
questions.explanation: Be specific. 'Kinetic energy', not 'energy'. 'Gravitational field strength', not 'gravity'. Precision matters.
questions.studyTip: Vague language = lost marks. Say exactly what you mean.

questions.text: Physics requires precise terminology to distinguish related but different concepts.
questions.explanation: Total energy vs kinetic energy. Weight vs mass. Speed vs velocity. Different things need different names.
questions.studyTip: If two words exist, there's a reason. Use the right one.

questions.text: In experiments, it's obvious which variables are independent and dependent from context.
questions.explanation: Explicitly identify them. Independent: what you change. Dependent: what you measure. Controlled: what stays constant.
questions.studyTip: State them clearly. Don't assume the assessor knows what you meant.

questions.text: Correctly identifying independent, dependent, and controlled variables shows experimental understanding.
questions.explanation: Getting these wrong indicates misunderstanding of the experiment's purpose.
questions.studyTip: I change [independent]. I measure [dependent]. I keep [controlled] constant.

questions.text: Stating that something happens is enough explanation for why it happens.
questions.explanation: Explain the mechanism. Don't just say transformers need AC — explain that AC creates changing flux, which induces EMF by Faraday's law.
questions.studyTip: Chain of reasoning: A causes B because of principle C, leading to D.

questions.text: Complete explanations describe the causal mechanism connecting cause to effect.
questions.explanation: Show how physics principles connect the starting conditions to the observed outcome.
questions.studyTip: Use 'because', 'therefore', 'this causes', 'which results in'.

questions.text: Strong relativity answers use both time dilation and length contraction for multiple perspectives.
questions.explanation: Pick one frame, one phenomenon. Mixing creates contradictions. Either time dilation OR length contraction, not both.
questions.studyTip: Commit to Earth frame (time dilation) or particle frame (length contraction).

questions.text: Using one frame of reference consistently prevents contradictions in relativity problems.
questions.explanation: Earth sees muon's time dilated. Muon sees distance contracted. Both explain detection. Pick one.
questions.studyTip: Start with 'In Earth's frame...' or 'In the muon's frame...' and stay there.

questions.text: For photoelectric questions, describing any one key finding briefly is enough for full marks.
questions.explanation: Pick one finding and explain it FULLY: What did wave model predict? What did experiment show? How does particle model explain it?
questions.studyTip: Depth on one finding beats shallow mentions of three.

questions.text: Complete photoelectric explanations contrast wave predictions, experimental results, and particle explanations.
questions.explanation: Three parts: (1) Wave model said... (2) Experiment showed... (3) Particle model explains because...
questions.studyTip: Structure: prediction vs observation vs explanation.

questions.text: For complex questions, start calculating immediately to show confidence.
questions.explanation: Plan first. What am I finding? What do I calculate? What do I compare? Then execute systematically.
questions.studyTip: Organised working = easier for assessor = better marks.

questions.text: Planning your approach before calculating produces more organised solutions.
questions.explanation: Students who dive in produce disorganised work with missing steps. Strategy first, execution second.
questions.studyTip: Write a brief plan: Step 1... Step 2... Conclusion.
